messages.content: You are ScholarAssist, an AI‑powered academic research assistant. You can search scholarly databases, retrieve paper metadata, extract core methods/results/conclusions, format citations in APA or MLA, summarise findings, and draft polished literature‑review sections in formal or neutral tone.
Please provide a formal draft literature‑review section on nanomaterial toxicity studies, complete with APA references.
Sure, I will start by searching PubMed for recent studies on nanomaterial toxicity.

- **Title:** Assessment of cytotoxicity of silver nanoparticles in human lung cells
  **Authors:** Liu, Y., Patel, R., & Kim, S.
  **Year:** 2022
  **DOI:** 10.1016/j.tox.2022.153456
  **Abstract:** *Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) are widely used in consumer products. This study evaluates their cytotoxic effects on human bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS‑2B). Viability assays revealed a dose‑dependent decrease in cell survival with an IC50 of 15 µg/mL. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and mitochondrial dysfunction were observed, indicating oxidative stress as a primary mechanism of toxicity.*

- **Title:** Gold nanorods induce oxidative stress in zebrafish embryos
  **Authors:** Martínez, L., O'Connor, D., & Singh, P.
  **Year:** 2021
  **DOI:** 10.1016/j.biocon.2021.108901
  **Abstract:** *Gold nanorods (GNRs) of ~50×15 nm were exposed to zebrafish (Danio rerio) embryos. Embryonic mortality increased with concentrations above 20 µg/mL. GNR exposure led to up‑regulation of hsp70 and sod1 genes, elevated lipid peroxidation, and impaired heart development, suggesting oxidative stress‑mediated teratogenicity.*

- **Title:** Long‑term exposure to titanium dioxide nanoparticles causes neuroinflammation in mice
  **Authors:** Chen, H., Wu, M., & García, A.
  **Year:** 2023
  **DOI:** 10.1038/s41598-023-11234
  **Abstract:** *Mice were fed TiO2 nanoparticles (10 nm) at 100 mg/kg diet for 12 months. Behavioral tests indicated cognitive deficits. Immunohistochemistry showed increased Iba1‑positive microglia in the hippocampus and elevated IL‑1β levels, confirming chronic neuroinflammation linked to nanoparticle accumulation.*

arguments.text: Silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) are widely used in consumer products. This study evaluates their cytotoxic effects on human bronchial epithelial cells (BEAS‑2B). Viability assays revealed a dose‑dependent decrease in cell survival with an IC50 of 15 µg/mL. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and mitochondrial dysfunction were observed, indicating oxidative stress as a primary mechanism of toxicity.

Gold nanorods (GNRs) of ~50×15 nm were exposed to zebrafish (Danio rerio) embryos. Embryonic mortality increased with concentrations above 20 µg/mL. GNR exposure led to up‑regulation of hsp70 and sod1 genes, elevated lipid peroxidation, and impaired heart development, suggesting oxidative stress‑mediated teratogenicity.

Mice were fed TiO2 nanoparticles (10 nm) at 100 mg/kg diet for 12 months. Behavioral tests indicated cognitive deficits. Immunohistochemistry showed increased Iba1‑positive microglia in the hippocampus and elevated IL‑1β levels, confirming chronic neuroinflammation linked to nanoparticle accumulation.

findings: - AgNPs cause dose‑dependent cytotoxicity in human lung cells via ROS generation and mitochondrial damage.
- GNRs are embryotoxic to zebrafish, provoking oxidative stress, gene expression changes, and heart malformations.
- TiO2 nanoparticles lead to chronic neuroinflammation and cognitive deficits in mice after prolonged exposure.

summaries: Recent experimental studies highlight that diverse nanomaterials elicit toxic effects through oxidative stress pathways, which manifest differently across cell types and organisms. Silver nanoparticles induce ROS‑mediated mitochondrial dysfunction in human bronchial epithelial cells, resulting in reduced viability (Liu et al., 2022). Gold nanorods provoke similar oxidative mechanisms in zebrafish embryos, leading to increased mortality, lipid peroxidation, and developmental abnormalities (Martínez et al., 2021). Chronic exposure to titanium dioxide nanoparticles in mice triggers sustained microglial activation and elevated pro‑inflammatory cytokines, culminating in neuroinflammation and impaired cognition (Chen et al., 2023).
